Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Infrastructure and ecosystem adaptations in the face of global climate change; Baltimore, Maryland, August, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
In August 2015, the Ecological Society of America (ESA) celebrates its centennial year with a major conference in Baltimore, MD. The meeting theme, Ecological Science at the Frontier, reflects back 100 years on ESA as a scientific society, as well as into the uncharted future of the planet. This award will provide partial support for one of the main products of that meeting, a centennial special issue of the ESA membership journal, Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, that looks forward to the next 100 years of life on Earth. Future generations will have to increasingly deal with the impacts of a changing climate in a wide range of practical ways. Many countries are already constructing or evaluating a range of new infrastructure prototypes, with the aim of supporting ecosystems and ecosystem services, and protecting human lives and property. It is critical that scientists are engaged in this discussion as investments are projected to increase dramatically over the next century. Therefore, ESA invited the authors to showcase the most interesting innovations around the world that address predicted future trajectories of change in ecosystems as climates change, and how humans might respond to those changes. Because all special issues of Frontiers are gold open access on the ESA website, this publication will be fully accessible to all interested readers. Authors are also welcome to post copies of their papers to their own personal or institutional websites, further increasing accessibility. Since Frontiers is designed to be understandable to a very broad audience, one way that scientists use it is as explanatory material when meeting with non-scientists, particularly resource managers and policy makers. As the planet changes, both the scientists and their stakeholder communities will benefit from having information on these infrastructural developments in one understandable package. Finally, this special issue will provide scientists with an early opportunity to develop related research agendas for addressing the challenges presented, the results of which will be critical to public policy as most regions of the world prepare to invest in adaptation.

Specific topics for this special issue of Frontiers include how infrastructure systems will respond to increased temperatures in cities, accelerating rates of sea level rise, long-term droughts, increased flooding, and species movements towards northern latitudes and higher elevations. Other topics focus on the changes in scientific understanding required for tracking and predicting major changes in ecosystems, in the form of both new statistical analyses and integrated models that cross scales from local populations of organisms to continents. Finally, this issue will also describe key modeling efforts that may influence our thinking about ecosystems in a changing climate and catalyze the development of new ideas related to coastal ecosystems, river and watershed dynamics, continental-scale biogeographic responses to climate change, and urban heat island effects related to human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global climate change is now widely recognized as one of the greatest threats to life on Earth – including humans. The associated effects now being measured and recorded by researchers around the world have almost become a cliché: sea level rise, floods, droughts, temperature extremes, terrestrial and aquatic pollution, deforestation, invasive species, and biodiversity loss, among others.

Governments are working to reach agreements on cutting greenhouse-gas emissions, to slow the progress of global climate change, but annual reports from respected international bodies such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change suggest that what has been achieved so far may be too little too late. As the impacts of climate change continue to be seen and felt, accompanied by predictions of worse to come, some countries have begun to build and test new infrastructure, designed to mitigate the most serious effects – particularly those associated with sea level rise, flooding, drought, increased temperatures, animal migrations, and the destruction of forests by wildfires, drought, and invasive species.

In 2015, the Ecological Society of America (ESA) celebrated its 100th anniversary, and its Annual Meeting included a large number of sessions on the effects of global climate change, as documented and reported by its members. As one of many products of this meeting, and in further celebration of the centennial, ESA’s journal, Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, commissioned articles for a Special Issue, highlighting some of the exciting infrastructural and other innovations being built and tested around the world in an effort to protect cities and natural ecosystems from the impacts of  climate change. Authors were encouraged to discuss the motivations behind, as well as the costs of, the different projects, the likelihood of their success both at the original site and in other regions or countries, and their actual and predicted ecological impacts.

Frontiers Special Issues cover timely ecological and environmental issues, thereby providing an accessible, easy-to-read overview of the topic, that can be understood by a broad, cross-disciplinary scientific readership as well as by policy makers, resource managers, educators, and students. Frontiers Special Issues are always gold open access, so the information is also freely available to the interested lay public.

The authors in the Special Issue include ecologists and environmental scientists as well as engineers, urban planners, and landscape designers, all of whom need to have a better understanding of these new adaptation strategies since they will have important effects on the performance and spatial distribution of systems and species.

One paper addressed new infrastructure elements designed to allow cities to adapt to rising seas and flooding, including constructed wetlands, huge mechanical moving barriers, and “water-proof” urban districts. Another article reviewed infrastructure that will mitigate the deadly effects of increasingly intense and longer-lasting heat waves in cities, including “green infrastructure” that brings plants and stormwater retention structures into highly paved urban areas, thereby increasing evaporation and evapotranspiration to reduce ambient temperature. Another paper described new decision support systems, based on the statistical identification of regime shifts in system behavior, as a way of predicting changes in urban lakes and rivers, based on their past behavior. A further paper discussed other issues affecting rivers, including the increasing role that urban wastewater effluent plays in sustaining river base-flows during droughts, and the need to clarify the definition of restoration for increasingly impacted rivers and streams. Finally, two articles addressed linkages across scales, one looking at the way forest ecosystems are modeled and measured, and the other describing how new land bridges over highway infrastructure can provide crucial pathways to support animal migration in response to a changing climate.

The Special Issue was published in November 2015 and was distributed broadly, both in print and online. The print issue was received by the almost 9000 members of the Society, and extra copies were sent to the authors, NSF as the funder, and others for distribution.  The issue has stimulated a lot of interest, both among researchers and a broader audience. The average Altmetrics score for the seven main articles is 43 (range 24 to 63; global average 5.5), which accounts for both mainstream news coverage and tweets, blogs, Facebook posts, and other social media “buzz”. The papers have been cited 16 times in the first 9 months since publication, and are expected to accrue more citations in the coming months.

It is hoped that the Special Issue will serve as a showcase for some of the innovative infrastructural projects, decision support tools, spatial strategies, and design prototypes currently being tested and that will have significant impacts on ecological systems and research in the next several decades. It was also intended to serve as inspiration for others to continue the development of practical solutions to the climate mitigation and adaptation challenges we face.
